speaker: DION
text_entry: SCENE II. A court of Justice.

speaker: DION
text_entry: Enter LEONTES, Lords, and Officers

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: This sessions, to our great grief we pronounce,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The daughter of a king, our wife, and one

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Of us too much beloved. Let us be clear'd

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Of being tyrannous, since we so openly

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Proceed in justice, which shall have due course,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Even to the guilt or the purgation.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Produce the prisoner.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: It is his highness' pleasure that the queen

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Appear in person here in court. Silence!

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Enter HERMIONE guarded; PAULINA and Ladies attending

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Read the indictment.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: [Reads]            Hermione, queen to the worthy

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Leontes, king of Sicilia, thou art here accused and

speaker: Officer
text_entry: arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery

speaker: Officer
text_entry: with Polixenes, king of Bohemia, and conspiring

speaker: Officer
text_entry: with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign

speaker: Officer
text_entry: lord the king, thy royal husband: the pretence

speaker: Officer
text_entry: whereof being by circumstances partly laid open,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: thou, Hermione, contrary to the faith and allegiance

speaker: Officer
text_entry: of a true subject, didst counsel and aid them, for

speaker: Officer
text_entry: their better safety, to fly away by night.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Since what I am to say must be but that

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Which contradicts my accusation and

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The testimony on my part no other

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: But what comes from myself, it shall scarce boot me

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To say 'not guilty:' mine integrity

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Being counted falsehood, shall, as I express it,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Be so received. But thus: if powers divine

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Behold our human actions, as they do,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I doubt not then but innocence shall make

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: False accusation blush and tyranny

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Tremble at patience. You, my lord, best know,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Who least will seem to do so, my past life

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: As I am now unhappy; which is more

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Than history can pattern, though devised

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And play'd to take spectators. For behold me

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: A fellow of the royal bed, which owe

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: A moiety of the throne a great king's daughter,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The mother to a hopeful prince, here standing

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Who please to come and hear. For life, I prize it

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: As I weigh grief, which I would spare: for honour,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: 'Tis a derivative from me to mine,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And only that I stand for. I appeal

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Came to your court, how I was in your grace,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: How merited to be so; since he came,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: With what encounter so uncurrent I

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Have strain'd to appear thus: if one jot beyond

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The bound of honour, or in act or will

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Cry fie upon my grave!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: I ne'er heard yet

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: That any of these bolder vices wanted

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Less impudence to gainsay what they did

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Than to perform it first.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: That's true enough;

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You will not own it.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: More than mistress of

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Which comes to me in name of fault, I must not

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: At all acknowledge. For Polixenes,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: With whom I am accused, I do confess

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I loved him as in honour he required,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: With such a kind of love as might become

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: A lady like me, with a love even such,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: So and no other, as yourself commanded:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Which not to have done I think had been in me

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Both disobedience and ingratitude

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: That it was yours. Now, for conspiracy,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I know not how it tastes; though it be dish'd

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: For me to try how: all I know of it

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Is that Camillo was an honest man;

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And why he left your court, the gods themselves,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Wotting no more than I, are ignorant.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You knew of his departure, as you know

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: What you have underta'en to do in's absence.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Sir,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: You speak a language that I understand not:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: My life stands in the level of your dreams,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Which I'll lay down.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Your actions are my dreams;

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: You had a bastard by Polixenes,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: And I but dream'd it. As you were past all shame,--

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Those of your fact are so--so past all truth:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Which to deny concerns more than avails; for as

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Thy brat hath been cast out, like to itself,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: No father owning it,--which is, indeed,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: More criminal in thee than it,--so thou

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Shalt feel our justice, in whose easiest passage

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Look for no less than death.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Sir, spare your threats:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The bug which you would fright me with I seek.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To me can life be no commodity:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The crown and comfort of my life, your favour,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I do give lost; for I do feel it gone,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: But know not how it went. My second joy

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: And first-fruits of my body, from his presence

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I am barr'd, like one infectious. My third comfort

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Starr'd most unluckily, is from my breast,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The innocent milk in its most innocent mouth,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Haled out to murder: myself on every post

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Proclaimed a strumpet: with immodest hatred

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The child-bed privilege denied, which 'longs

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: To women of all fashion; lastly, hurried

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Here to this place, i' the open air, before

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I have got strength of limit. Now, my liege,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Tell me what blessings I have here alive,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: That I should fear to die? Therefore proceed.

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: But yet hear this: mistake me not; no life,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I prize it not a straw, but for mine honour,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Which I would free, if I shall be condemn'd

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Upon surmises, all proofs sleeping else

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: But what your jealousies awake, I tell you

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: 'Tis rigor and not law. Your honours all,

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: I do refer me to the oracle:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Apollo be my judge!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: This your request

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Is altogether just: therefore bring forth,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And in Apollos name, his oracle.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt certain Officers

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The Emperor of Russia was my father:

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: O that he were alive, and here beholding

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: His daughter's trial! that he did but see

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: The flatness of my misery, yet with eyes

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Of pity, not revenge!

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Re-enter Officers, with CLEOMENES and DION

speaker: Officer
text_entry: You here shall swear upon this sword of justice,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: That you, Cleomenes and Dion, have

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Been both at Delphos, and from thence have brought

speaker: Officer
text_entry: The seal'd-up oracle, by the hand deliver'd

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Of great Apollo's priest; and that, since then,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: You have not dared to break the holy seal

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Nor read the secrets in't.

speaker: DION
text_entry: All this we swear.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Break up the seals and read.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: [Reads] Hermione is chaste;

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Polixenes blameless; Camillo a true subject; Leontes

speaker: Officer
text_entry: a jealous tyrant; his innocent babe truly begotten;

speaker: Officer
text_entry: and the king shall live without an heir, if that

speaker: Officer
text_entry: which is lost be not found.

speaker: Lords
text_entry: Now blessed be the great Apollo!

speaker: HERMIONE
text_entry: Praised!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Hast thou read truth?

speaker: Officer
text_entry: Ay, my lord; even so

speaker: Officer
text_entry: As it is here set down.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: There is no truth at all i' the oracle:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The sessions shall proceed: this is mere falsehood.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Enter Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord the king, the king!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: What is the business?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: O sir, I shall be hated to report it!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: The prince your son, with mere conceit and fear

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Of the queen's speed, is gone.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: How! gone!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Is dead.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Apollo's angry; and the heavens themselves

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Do strike at my injustice.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: HERMIONE swoons

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: How now there!

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: This news is mortal to the queen: look down

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: And see what death is doing.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Take her hence:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Her heart is but o'ercharged; she will recover:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: I have too much believed mine own suspicion:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Beseech you, tenderly apply to her

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Some remedies for life.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Exeunt PAULINA and Ladies, with HERMIONE

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Apollo, pardon

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: My great profaneness 'gainst thine oracle!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: I'll reconcile me to Polixenes,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: New woo my queen, recall the good Camillo,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Whom I proclaim a man of truth, of mercy;

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: For, being transported by my jealousies

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Camillo for the minister to poison

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: My friend Polixenes: which had been done,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: But that the good mind of Camillo tardied

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: My swift command, though I with death and with

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Reward did threaten and encourage him,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Not doing 't and being done: he, most humane

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: And fill'd with honour, to my kingly guest

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Unclasp'd my practise, quit his fortunes here,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Which you knew great, and to the hazard

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Of all encertainties himself commended,

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: No richer than his honour: how he glisters

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Thorough my rust! and how his pity

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Does my deeds make the blacker!

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Re-enter PAULINA

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Woe the while!

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Break too.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: What fit is this, good lady?

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me?

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling?

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: In leads or oils? what old or newer torture

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Must I receive, whose every word deserves

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To taste of thy most worst? Thy tyranny

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Together working with thy jealousies,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: For girls of nine, O, think what they have done

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: And then run mad indeed, stark mad! for all

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing;

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: That did but show thee, of a fool, inconstant

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: And damnable ingrateful: nor was't much,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To have him kill a king: poor trespasses,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: More monstrous standing by: whereof I reckon

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To be or none or little; though a devil

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Would have shed water out of fire ere done't:

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: That could conceive a gross and foolish sire

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Blemish'd his gracious dam: this is not, no,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Laid to thy answer: but the last,--O lords,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: and vengeance for't

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Not dropp'd down yet.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The higher powers forbid!

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Prevail not, go and see: if you can bring

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Heat outwardly or breath within, I'll serve you

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: As I would do the gods. But, O thou tyrant!

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Do not repent these things, for they are heavier

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To nothing but despair. A thousand knees

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Upon a barren mountain and still winter

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: In storm perpetual, could not move the gods

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To look that way thou wert.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Go on, go on

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: All tongues to talk their bitterest.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Say no more:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I' the boldness of your speech.

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: I am sorry for't:

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: All faults I make, when I shall come to know them,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: I do repent. Alas! I have show'd too much

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: The rashness of a woman: he is touch'd

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: To the noble heart. What's gone and what's past help

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Should be past grief: do not receive affliction

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: At my petition; I beseech you, rather

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Let me be punish'd, that have minded you

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Of what you should forget. Now, good my liege

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Sir, royal sir, forgive a foolish woman:

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!--

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: I'll speak of her no more, nor of your children;

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: I'll not remember you of my own lord,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: Who is lost too: take your patience to you,

speaker: PAULINA
text_entry: And I'll say nothing.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Thou didst speak but well

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: When most the truth; which I receive much better

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Than to be pitied of thee. Prithee, bring me

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: To the dead bodies of my queen and son:

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: One grave shall be for both: upon them shall

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The causes of their death appear, unto

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Our shame perpetual. Once a day I'll visit

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Shall be my recreation: so long as nature

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Will bear up with this exercise, so long

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: I daily vow to use it. Come and lead me

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Unto these sorrows.

speaker: LEONTES
text_entry: Exeunt
